data.title: Add writable data path next to the possibly read-only data path
data.body:
The data path may point to the read only directory like
/app/Superpowers/core inside the flatpak sandbox. So we added the path
to the writable data directory which can be set with the
--rw-data-path option when running the server. This is where sessions,
superpowers, systems, config, plugins JSON files can be written.

I'm not sure if the patch is complete, but before continuing it, would this effort be welcome? By the way, the flatpak for superpowers I was working on is here - https://github.com/endlessm/superpowers-flatpak. You can read about flatpak here - http://flatpak.org. We use it at endless to provide applications.

I also have PRs for the game and app, will xref them there, when filing.

data.title: Possible bug in ArcadeBody2D
Supclient: fetch: workaround for ie11.
data.body:
Add a workaround for IE11 in SupClient/src/fetch.ts.

IE11 doesn't automatically parse the XHR response as JSON even though "responseType" is set to "JSON" (it gives a string back instead). Try to detect and correct this issue at runtime.

I don't know what superpowers's policy on older browsers is, but given the simplicity of this workaround, I think it's worth merging it.

data.title: Hot key1a
data.body:
This PR is code for a proposed HotKeyManager  to enable dynamic editing of hotkey definitions as I described  in https://github.com/superpowers/superpowers-core/issues/129
This is part 1 of a 2 part request.  The 2nd PR will appear shortly on superpowers-game repo.

data.title: Error - only a single primitive is supported - Importing 3D asset.
data.body:
Probably a simple fix but I get the error "Only a single primitive is supported."

I made sure to only export the body of this helicopter from Blender and then convert to the gltf format. I checked by re-importing my .dae file to blender and there is in fact only a single prim.

Not sure what I am doing wrong here.

To be clear I found this asset on TurboSquid just to test with using Superpowers and from what I can see in blender it looks fine to me.

data.title: Update italian (it) localization
Prevent creating a project when no system is installed, closes #147
Prevent creating a project if no system is installed.
data.body:
Someone in French Skype group had this issue:

> " The server crashed while loading project "artemyx".
> Error: The system  is not installed."

It looks like we might be allowing people to create a project with no system selected at all, probably  when they declined installing Superpowers Game. We should prevent creating a project if no system is installed.

data.title: Sup.exit()
data.body:
`Sup.exit()` does not work with Electron version greater than v0.37.8

An error appears after you export the game, and used with Electron:
`Uncaught Error: Cannot find module 'remote'`

data.title: Why the software history was not kept?
data.body:
Hi there,

I'm a researcher studying software evolution. As part of my current research, I'm studying the implications of open-sourcing a proprietary software, for instance, if the project succeed in attracting newcomers. However, I observed that some projects, like _superpowers-core_, deleted their software history when transitioning to open-source.

https://github.com/superpowers/superpowers-core/commit/027ed12b46e6eb8bcc3cf1464ddbe9c8e914f540

Knowing that software history is indispensable for developers (e.g., developers need to refer to history several times a day), I would like to ask superpowers-core developers the following four brief questions:
1. Why did you decide to not keep the software history?
2. Do the core developers faced any kind of problems, when trying to refer to the old history? If so, how did they solve these problems?
3. Do the newcomers faced any kind of problems, when trying to refer to the old history? If so, how did they solve these problems?
4. How does the lack of history impacted on software evolution? Does it placed any burden in understanding and evolving the software?

Thanks in advance for your collaboration,

Gustavo Pinto, PhD
http://www.gustavopinto.org

data.title: Attempting to edit script from cloned git repo results in being disconnected from server
data.body:
This problem occurs with Windows 10, 64-bit, using both the Superpowers editor both using the desktop app and from the browser.

Steps to reproduce:
- git clone "discover-superpowers" repo into projects directory
- Start superpowers server and begin editing discover-superpowers project
- Open Player Behavior and attempt to edit script
- Get "You were disconnected." message

The same problem does not occur if I make a new script via Superpowers and attempt to edit it--the problem only occurs with scripts from the repository. It seems like it could be some sort of file permissions issue, but I didn't have any trouble editing the files with any other editors.

data.title: Typescript error checking is extremely slow
data.body:
I'm using version 0.22.0-dev and I've used both electron 1.1.1 and Google Chrome to try to edit projects. In both cases, (Even though Chrome was better) the script editor got extremely laggy. On Chrome, it seemed to get worse over time over time. In electron, it was slow from the start. Typing a single character would freeze the screen for a good few seconds while it attempts to detect errors. It's even worse when trying to do a multi-line comment, as it becomes almost impossible to close the comment because of the freeze checking the rest of the lines that were unintentionally commented. This makes superpowers almost completely unusable.

I'm on a lower-end laptop, but it should be able to handle a code editor, right?

[Here is a gif](http://imgur.com/6Iynj8G). It's kinda painful to watch :p.
Since it's hard to tell, this is what is going on:
1. I opened the script asset. Notice the long loading time. During this loading time, I attempted to change the cursor position and scroll down.
2. When the scrolling finally worked, I scrolled to the bottom and added 2 new lines.
3. After that, I typed some words at a normal typing speed. They didn't appear until much later.
4. After they did appear, there was yet another delay as the editor attempted to find errors. During this time,  I attempted to change the cursor position a few times and select something.
5. Finally, I commented what I wrote. It froze again and took a while to realize that there were no more errors.

This doesn't happen in the latest stable release (0.19.0). This is probably a critical issue :D.

data.title: Handle exit on kill command for command start
data.body: Added line to start.ts to handle when the user kills the process using the kill command

data.title: Systematically disconnected when trying to modify a script
data.body:
I'm using Superpowers 0.19.0 for Windows 64-bit (with Windows 7).

In a project I have a few scripts that I'm not able to modify because I'm being disconnected everytime I write a single digit/character in the script (even if it's a space or a line-break). Other script in this project work just right, and my other Superpowers projects are working fine too.

If I duplicate these scripts assets (either with ctrl + D or by copy/pasting in a new script asset), I just run into the same problem (systematically disconnected).

I did a few Git manipulations just before this problem occured, so I believe it's related. (I reset the project to a former stage and deleted an empty branch) I'm not really used to Git (or even versionning) so I believe I just screwed up by myself, but I believe the behavior of those... well, Behaviors was worth pointing out.

data.title: Can't build from source - missing client/index.js
data.body:
I've tried to pull the repo and build from source so I can start trying to tackle some of the open issues, but after following the build instructions I hit an error when the build script tries to build the client folder, it's expecting an index.js, but it's not there.

The client folder contains an index.d.ts, but not an index.ts, which I presume is the problem, but I have no idea what that file should contain, so I can't really fix the issue myself.
